headline: A Lot Happening Here
pros:
- Management Hierarchy is good. Anyone from anywhere can pick up the phone and dial anyone from the directors. Approachable which builds trust. 
- Lots of learning here if you know how to figure that out. Way too many projects keep starting, new feature launches happening, sales hackathons, etc. Learning here is more macro-level and should you see things that way, you will learn how various processes and teams get things moving. Good place to learn organized execution if you wish to start something of your own.
- Transparency. You want to know something, you will almost always get a transparent answer (depending on the sensitivity of the subject).
cons:
- Delays happen a lot. Things don't move as fast as you expect them to. Some features which were supposed to be rolled out in November are still pending because they went down on the priority level. Projects and plans get shelved sometimes without explanations. This can't necessarily be called a con since this is a necessary evil for startups and bidding firms. Business tides change fast and so does the steering but why this is important to point out is that it affects people. Not everyone is able to align with delays and change in plans quickly. Can this be avoided? Yes, with regular and sufficient expectation setting. 
- Expectation Setting doesn't exist here. Nobody will set your expectations right which leads to disgruntled employees. Expectations around career growth, personal growth, stability, security, workload, turbulence, etc needs to be set during joining and from then on periodically so that the company can separate the wheat from the chaff. Not everyone is built to work crazy hours and not everyone can take startup pressure. Frequent Expectation setting will set this right. 
- Stagnant Career Growth - No IJPs, no new positions come up. People who've been here from the last 3-5 years haven't moved up or even sideways (different parallel roles). Since the current hiring situation outside isn't good, attrition is under control. The moment the hiring situation gets better, we may witness an exodus - good employees who've been stagnant for years.

headline: An organisation that challenges you to raise the bar higher each day!
pros:

People are actually driven towards solving business problems (both long and short term) and are given a free hand at devising their own methods of arriving at solutions. The vision to create the one-stop marketplace for offline services in the online world is something that challenges people everyday and forces them to raise the bar.

3. Office: Extremely spacious and lively office space in Gurgaon - has amenities / infrastructure that very few can boast of. Ensures that the employee is comfortable during work hours and provides individuals with a lot of personal space to be productive. 

4. Co-founders: The promoting team of the organisation are rockstars...always upbeat, extremely kind and welcoming of suggestions, they are the ones who walk the talk and truly lead by example. One of the main reasons why the open work culture bodes well at nearbuy is because of the attitude of the co-founders.

headline: #workisplay@nearbuy!
pros:

Career Opportunities - If you work hard, are ambitious and have the potential to scale up in your role nearbuy provides enough and more opportunities for career development. It is not only limited to one's current function but employees are also given a fair chance to transition within functions if they have the required skill and interest. 

Work Life Balance/ Personal Commitments - The management is very understanding and encourages fair treatment of both professional and personal commitments if the job role allows for flexibility at a given point in time. As a first hand experience I received more than thoughtful consideration on my health concerns or when I had to work from another location due to personal commitments and my manager helped me charting out a plan to manage my responsibilities at work and at home. For an organisation so young this certainly is a very trusting and mature approach to managing employee wellbeing.
cons: There should be more emphasis on long term development of skills and capability at all levels.
